intro: Allocarya jucunda, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its striking yellow to orange bell-shaped flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters and has slender, branched stems covered in fine hairs. Its leaves are narrow and lanceolate, often with a slightly hairy surface. Allocarya jucunda thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or alpine environments.
